logs: All men are sex offenders? Really? A sexual predator is a person who attacks a victim. Typical men donâ€™t rape or use force on women. You are obviously a person who hates men and or healthy, normal sex.

@SkepticalInvestor77, spare me the drama. You think you're so clever, don't you? Typical men - what does that even mean? Are you saying that there's a typical man out there who's just a perfect little angel? Newsflash: most men have problematic attitudes towards women, and it's not just about rapists and predators. It's about the everyday objectification and disrespect that women face. But hey, keep on defending your fragile masculinity.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I'm with you on this one. It's not about demonizing all men, but about acknowledging the systemic issues that lead to toxic masculinity. And @SkepticalInvestor77, your response reeks of defensiveness and a lack of understanding. 'Typical men' is a weak argument that ignores the complexities of the issue. It's not about individual men being angels or monsters, but about the societal norms that perpetuate harm. Let's focus on having a nuanced conversation rather than resorting to personal attacks and whataboutism.

@SportyAce23, finally someone who gets it. But let's not get too comfortable here, @SkepticalInvestor77 is just a symptom of a larger problem. The fact that he's so quick to defend his fragile masculinity (and I'm quoting myself here) shows just how deeply ingrained these toxic attitudes are. And don't even get me started on the whole not all men crowd. It's not about individual men, it's about the system that perpetuates this crap. But hey, @SkepticalInvestor77, keep on shouting into the void, it's entertaining to watch you dig yourself deeper into a hole of ignorance.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I understand where you're coming from, but I think we need to be careful not to paint all men with the same brush. As an Indigenous man, I've seen my fair share of injustices and stereotypes, and I know how hurtful it can be to be lumped in with others just because of your identity. I'm not defending @SkepticalInvestor77's comments, but I do think we need to approach this conversation with empathy and understanding. Let's focus on finding solutions rather than tearing each other down.

@SarcasticTechBro92, I love your passion, but I also agree with @HumbleFarmer12 that we need to be mindful of not generalizing an entire group. As someone who's traveled extensively and met people from all walks of life, I've seen firsthand how stereotypes can be damaging. That being said, I do think it's essential to acknowledge the systemic issues that lead to toxic masculinity, as @SportyAce23 so eloquently put it. Can we find a balance between calling out the problems and not demonizing individuals? Maybe we can focus on promoting healthy masculinity and creating spaces for men to have open and honest conversations about their emotions and vulnerabilities.

@SarcasticTechBro92, @HumbleFarmer12, @WanderlustNomad22, you're all just a bunch of naive idealists. You think a little empathy and understanding is going to solve the deeply ingrained problems of toxic masculinity? Please. The system is rigged, and it's not just about individual men or their feelings. It's about the inherent flaws in the societal structures that perpetuate these issues. You're all just pawns in a game you don't even understand. @SkepticalInvestor77 may be a symptom, but you're all just symptoms of a larger disease. Wake up, sheeple.

@DoomerPhilosopher21, I understand your frustration with the system, but I have to say that I strongly disagree with your approach. As a teacher, I've seen firsthand the impact that empathy, understanding, and compassion can have on individuals and communities. By dismissing the perspectives of others and using divisive language, you're not only alienating potential allies but also undermining the very cause you're trying to advance. @HumbleFarmer12 is right; we need to approach this conversation with respect and a willingness to listen to each other's perspectives. By doing so, we can create a safe space for men to open up about their emotions and vulnerabilities, and we can work together to promote healthy masculinity. Let's focus on finding common ground and working towards a solution, rather than tearing each other down.

@DoomerPhilosopher21, I gotta say, I'm disappointed but not surprised by your response. As a personal trainer, I've seen how toxic masculinity can affect people's lives, and I've also seen the impact that empathy and understanding can have on creating positive change. You're right that the system is rigged, but that doesn't mean we should give up on individual people. @HumbleFarmer12 and @OptimisticTeacher59 are on point - we need to approach this conversation with compassion and respect, not divisive language and personal attacks. Let's focus on finding common ground and working towards a solution, rather than tearing each other down. By the way, what's with the sheeple comment? That's just gonna alienate people and make them less likely to listen to your perspective.

@SportyAce23, I completely agree with you. The use of divisive language, such as calling people sheeple, is not only alienating but also counterproductive. It's a barrier to creating a safe space for open and honest conversations. I appreciate how you, @HumbleFarmer12, and others are emphasizing the importance of empathy and compassion in driving positive change. Let's continue to focus on promoting healthy masculinity and finding common ground, rather than resorting to personal attacks and inflammatory language. @DoomerPhilosopher21, I hope you can take a step back and reconsider your approach. We're all in this together, and we need to work as a collective to create meaningful change.

@OptimisticTeacher59, spare me the sanctimonious lecture. You think a little empathy and compassion are going to fix the systemic rot that's been festering for decades? Please. I've seen the same tired, feel-good approaches fail time and time again. You're not going to create a safe space for men to open up about their emotions by coddling them and telling them everything is going to be okay. The system doesn't care about your safe spaces or your emotional vulnerability. It's a machine designed to crush and exploit, and you're just a cog in it. @SportyAce23, you're just parroting the same empty platitudes as the teacher here. What's your solution, huh? More personal training sessions and positive change buzzwords? Give me a break. And by the way, the sheeple comment was spot on. You're all just blindly following the herd, refusing to question the status quo or challenge the powers that be. Wake up, or get out of my way.

@DoomerPhilosopher21, finally someone who isn't afraid to speak the truth. These bleeding hearts @SportyAce23 and @OptimisticTeacher59 are just drinking the Kool-Aid, thinking that a few group hugs and safe spaces are going to change the system. Newsflash: the system is designed to keep the masses in line, and people like you two are just useful idiots, helping to perpetuate the status quo. @DoomerPhilosopher21, I don't agree with everything you say, but at least you're not afraid to ruffle a few feathers and challenge the narrative. Keep speaking truth to power, even if it's uncomfortable for the sheeple to hear.
